options.content:
# **üöÄ kube-burner-ocp virt capacity benchmark dashboard**

This dashboard provides deep insights into the results of the virt-capacity-benchmark execution using kube-burner-ocp. For a deep dive into workload parameters and metric definitions, refer to the [official kube-burner-ocp documentation](https://kube-burner.github.io/kube-burner-ocp/latest/#virt-capacity-benchmark).

### ‚öôÔ∏è How to configure your view

Use the dropdown selectors at the top of the dashboard to filter the results:

- **Run UUID üîΩ:** Select the unique identifier for your benchmark execution to filter all visualizations for that specific test run.
- **Latency Percentile üìä:** Toggle between median (50th) for typical performance or tail latencies (90th/95th/99th) to identify worst-case bottlenecks in your infrastructure.

üìå **NOTE:**
- All latency metrics in this dashboard are reported in seconds.
- Since the OS image is provisioned through persistent storage instead of being pulled directly into the `virt-launcher` pod‚Äôs local directory, this scenario results in the creation and binding of DataVolumes and PVCs.

targets.query: jobName.keyword:"create-vms-0" AND metricName.keyword:"dvLatencyMeasurement" AND replica: 1 AND uuid:"$uuid"

panels.description: This panel compares the average wall-clock duration of each benchmark phase across all iterations. It highlights which job consumes the most time, identifying potential infrastructure bottlenecks.
panels.title: Average phase duration comparison

targets.query: jobName.keyword:create-vms-* AND metricName.keyword:"dvLatencyMeasurement" AND uuid:"$uuid" AND dvName.keyword:*-root

panels.description:
Breaks down the total VM creation time into six distinct phases:

   1. VMI provisioning (Created): Captures API overhead and initial storage preparation. In Immediate binding mode, this includes the full DataVolume/PVC provisioning and binding time.
   2. Controller handoff (Pending): Measures virt-controller efficiency in processing the VMI and generating the launcher Pod spec while waiting for storage availability.
   3. Scheduling & Binding (Scheduling): Critical for WaitForFirstConsumer storage. Captures the dual latency of the Scheduler selecting a node and the Storage Provisioner binding the volume to that node's topology.
   4. Node & Mount prep (Scheduled): Captures Kubelet overhead, including pulling the virt-launcher image and the physical attachment/mounting of storage volumes to the worker node.
   5. Hypervisor startup (Running): Confirms the hypervisor is launched and all storage/network interfaces are attached and accessible to the virtual hardware.
   6. Virtual Machine readiness (Ready): Time from Running to the Ready condition. Confirms all DataVolumes are ready and the KubeVirt Guest Agent has established a connection with the host handler.
panels.title: VM provisioning lifecycle breakdown

targets.query: jobName.keyword:create-vms-* AND metricName.keyword:"dvLatencyMeasurement" AND uuid:"$uuid" AND dvName.keyword:*-data-*

panels.description: Displays the distribution of VMs across physical nodes to track workload density and cluster balance.
panels.title: Distribution of VMs per host

panels.description: Displays the distribution of VMs across physical nodes to track workload density and cluster balance.
panels.title: VM ready latency per host (Average)

panels.description: This panel calculates the total wall-clock time for the Resize Volumes phase using the elapsedTime field from the jobSummary measurement. This derived metric is used because specific granular resize volume latencies are currently unavailable
panels.title: Volume resize execution duration

panels.description: This panel calculates the total wall-clock time for the Restart VMs phase using the elapsedTime field from the jobSummary measurement. This derived metric is used because specific granular restart latencies are currently unavailable
panels.title: Restart VMs execution duration

panels.description: This panel calculates the total wall-clock time for the Snapshot VMs phase using the elapsedTime field from the jobSummary measurement. This derived metric is used because specific granular snapshot latencies are currently unavailable
panels.title: Snapshot VMs execution duration

panels.description:
This panel displays the average time VMs take to complete migration and reach a Ready state.

NOTE: Latency includes queuing time; if you trigger more than the KubeVirt parallel limit (default 5), values will increase as VMs wait to start.
panels.title: VM migration ready latency (Average)

panels.description:
Breaks down the total VM migration time into six distinct phases:
   0. Pending: The migration is accepted by the system.
   1. Scheduling: The migration's target pod is being scheduled.
   2. Scheduled: The migration's target pod is running.
   3. PreparingTarget:  The migration's target pod is being prepared for migration.
   4. TargetReady: The migration's target pod is prepared and ready for migration.
   5. Running: The migration is in progress.
   6. Succeeded: The migration passed.
panels.title: VM migration lifecycle breakdown

list.description: Filters the dashboard to show performance metrics for the selected virt-capacity benchmark run ID
list.label: Run UUID
list.name: uuid

list.description: Selects the P-value (50th to 99th) for VM and DV latency calculations
list.label: Latency Percentile
list.name: percentile
